pros: The staff members are smart, interesting and great to work with.

pros: A great school committed to helping students on their academic and professional journeys.

pros: Minimum wage in Massachusetts is nice. Great way to be a part of a community and also make money on the side.
cons: The 10 hour cap is pretty ridiculous. A lot of students work over 10 hours and then struggle to get compensated.

pros: Generally not too stressful, hours are clear and students are easy to guide.

pros: A good student job, no complaints!

pros: Good part time job to get some money

pros: Nice campus, nice offices, lots of resources. Pet-friendly and can be flexible about scheduling if you have the right job/supervisor. I feel like I have the manpower and tools to support my position in whatever I might need.
cons: Little to no career path, very small raises, not many professional development opportunities for hourly staff. The culture of management is all over the place so your job could be really good or really bad depending on our manager.

cons: No downsides to speak of!

pros: Great intellectual environment to work and learn! Great place for people who love hiking and museums.
cons: If you don´t own a car, it´s a little isolated. Also, I didn´t have enough diverse restaurants to go to.

pros: Presenting at the planetarium is great for people who are both interested in science and education! I love building shows that cover both astrophysics and mythology to inspire the audience in the wonders of the cosmos.
cons: Finding time to work as a student can be difficult, but with some proactive organization, it becomes far more manageable.

pros: there are a wide range of available jobs so you can find something that fits your interests and bosses understand that you are a student and balancing that as well.

pros: good boss, fun work, decent pay

job_title: Public Relations Intern in Boston, MA
pros: Everyone at this museum is determined to help you succeed. You make a lot of great connections and are allowed to participate in any part of the museum process that you're interested in. I learned so much in just one short year I was here. Also, for such a small museum, WCMA puts on incredibly complex and stunning shows.
cons: Williamstown is very rural--any full-time positions would have to consider the isolated area.

pros: Great work life balance as an hourly wmployee

pros: I like it a lot.

pros: Benefits; professional development; colleagues; work/life balance

pros: As a student, HR was helpful when I started working. My supervisors were also friendly and helpful

review_title: They know they are the largest employer in town and act it.
pros: Intelligent co-workers, students keep you young, nice area of the country, good benefits (especially for administrative staff or you have lots of kids going to college), accommodating if you need time off, summers are quiet.
cons: This employer's industry is education, yet, if you want to take classes to get a degree, they won't pay for it. They will only pay for classes if they directly involve your job.  And then, only if the classes are at night so you don't miss work. (Although, I know some people who HAVE had their bachelor degrees paid for, but they are administrative staff.) There is no such thing as a MERIT raise--it doesn't matter how hard you work, how great your work ethic is. I see people who have a wonderful work ethic passed over for raises while people whose work ethic is poor get raises.  It's who you know, not what you do.  Forget it if you think working hard, being smart, and giving 110% will get you a promotion--it won't!

pros: Great Education-- passionate professors, intelligent students, good amenities
cons: Can feel isolating if don't make close friends

pros:
-Good opportunities to become familiar with new material.
-Professors tend to be very responsive to your input.
-Learning through the lens of a teaching position always adds value.
-Average to competitive student TA pay.
-Williams College is nestled in the Berkshire Purple Valley. The fresh air, beautiful scenery and friendly local population make Williamstown a great place to live and work
cons:
-Some professors can be unhelpful or unsupportive.
-TA roles, responsibilities, and work load can be incredibly disproportional to job expectations or those of peers.
-Some people will be unhappy working in a town with little to no night life, few restaurants, and otherwise very few attractions.

review_title: Overall Positive Experience WIth Some Minor Blemishes
job_title: Schow Library Clerk in Williamstown, MA
pros: Due in large part to its wealth, the college is in a good position to take care of its employees.  Hourly wages are fair, and there is a strong sense of community among employees.
cons: As often happens in very traditional settings, sometimes people end up retaining a position that they are not necessarily suited for.  This turns out unfortunately when lower ranking employees are more knowledgeable than their supervisors.

job_title: Student Events Assistant in Williamstown, MA
pros: There are semi-flexible hours, you get to work with peers, time to study (usually), and the afternoons are normally easygoing. Working in the '62 Center for Theatre and Dance, you can see all the shows for free (even though they are cheap anyway) and sometimes meet visiting artists, help out behind the scenes, and network.
cons: Unfortunately, the managers may occasionally lack professionalism and be unhelpful during very busy times, such as busy evening performances. Also, there are occasional technical difficulties that make a busy time nearly impossible to get through. Crowd control can also be a problem, especially if communication is poor or there is misinformation printed anywhere.

pros: Professors are usually very kind and helpful. They sometimes would provide the solutions for grading which saves TAs time to come up with solutions themselves for grading problem sets. The deadlines for finish grading are often flexible too.
cons: The hourly pay is low compared to many other colleges. Also, lower level classes may have a huge class size (20+) and maximum hours per week allowed is only 10 hours, so sometimes TAs have to work extra hours without getting compensated for the extra hours.

review_title: Great experience as a Chem tutor
pros: The hours are completely flexible (self-determined) and the salary is better than most campus jobs. Incentives to tutor many students, as the pay rate increases when that is done.
cons: There are no real cons to this job. A select few students are harder to help than others; it's obvious that they don't do any homework/studying on their own, so the task of helping them becomes more arduous. You end up assuming they understand absolutely nothing about the topic at hand --including prerequisite information-- which slows the process down completely (once in a while to a painful degree). This can make the job boring.

pros:
Great perks and faculty incentives- travel money, relocation, flush with internal funds for pedagogical groups, speaker honoraria, or any reasonable request beyond the typical research allotment. Nice, small campus feel. 
Great, highly motivated students, supportive administrators. Good departmental support.
Inexpensive campus housing.
cons:
Campus housing stock is inadequate, and many units suffer from deferred maintenance issues (no insulation, pests, water in basement, plumbing problems, etc, etc). 
Also, the campus housing lottery privileges those with seniority. As a result, those most in need (e.g. new faculty and especially contract faculty) don't have access to most of it.

review_title: There's more work to do here than one can actually get done.
pros: Almost everyone here is extremely intelligent and are interesting to talk to.  The students are almost uniformly gifted and most are wonderful people.
cons: There's too much work and too many competing interests.  Sometimes it feels like the institution is struggling to define itself.  Almost everyone works themselves to exhaustion.  Institutional memory concerning how important buildings on campus actually operate has somehow gotten "lost."

pros: Small, supportive community.  Great benefits.  Beautiful location.  Intelligent interesting people.  Lots of latitude to pursue your own projects.  Can take advantage of whole range of campus events and resources, including library, theater productions, athletic facilities, etc.  Positive management.
cons: Williamstown can be a tough place to work for young professionals, because, in general, young people there are either students are are starting families.  There's not much middle ground.

pros:
- one on one professor interactions
- lab immersion in research jobs 
- opportunity to do research as a work study job if extra money is needed
The job of a research assistant is pretty flexible. I am never pressured to put in extra hours and my PI is very supportive of my ideas as well.
cons: Some people complain that the TA jobs are low wage since many times, students who need tutoring may stay over past shift time. Don't get any type of raise over undergrad career.

pros: Good pay, excellent benefits and many good and caring people to work with.  The college offers training in-house and employees can get discounts at many local companies.  Excellent 403B retirement program and tuition assistance to families of employees. Health and wellness programs are also offered.
cons: There is not a lot of room for people to move around within the college if you did not attend Williams or have a spouse that did.

review_title: I have had a very positive experience as a micro Econ tutor
pros:
Hours are entirely self-determined
Salary is generous in comparison to other student salaries
Employers really like this particular credential
You reinforce your own Econ skills while helping to develop them in others
cons:
Some students require more patience then others
Often people submit tutoring requests only when they are in dire need
Logging hours, going through administrative training can be a drag

pros: You get paid well to do a job that is fun and value-add, and there is very limited oversight or supervision.
cons: Sometimes when it's freezing cold and there a ton of skates to do you have to walk to the rink in the middle of the day.

pros: They take great care to thoroughly orient and train new employees. The benefits are unparalleled. They give you the resources and the time to do your job to the best of your ability.
cons: None, really. Base salary can be a bit lower than other employers, but they more than compensate with generous retirement savings plan and incredible college tuition benefit for dependent children.

pros: I always felt a strong sense of commitment among employees. Supervisors or older employees always respected student employees. Pay for student manager's was very fair.
cons: I did not always feel as though our supervising department put enough care or energy into our division. There were many rules and regulations that required supervisor's signature which took many weeks, or more, to receive.

pros: Good preparation, good support network. Great environment for students to grow and thrieve.
cons: Isolated from bg cities creates an insulated and small social as well as professional setting which keeps training/internship oportunities at a minimum.

pros: The pay was good, the work was pretty interesting. It's a great place to be in the summer and everyone seems much less stressed out than during the year.
cons: The food is crappy unless you eat at the Faculty Club. Honestly, I don't really have much negative to say about working at Williams over the summer besides that.

pros: Worked at the Office of Information Technology with a lot of great guys with a good community feel. Everyone gets to know each other with meetings every week to discuss each others work.
cons: Sometimes have days where youre not sure if you accomplished much. Other days you are working on projects all day long.

review_title: Excellent, inclusive, and informative program run by James McAllister; highly recommend.
pros: Small groups and teams with excellent levels of cooperation. Class sessions are highly intensive and information-heavy, demanding involvement from all members of the program.
cons: Odd mix of people admitted to the program sometimes became frustrating and difficult to work with due to varying levels of baseline knowledge.

review_title: Wonderful experience in the Williams Writing Center
job_title: Writing Center Tutor in Williamstown, MA
pros: Wonderful, cooperative working environment and valuable experiences to connect with fellow students on-on-one.  One of the best-paid student jobs.
cons: No cons! It was a great experience and I had the opportunity to connect with writers and professors in workshops focused on their writing style.

job_title: Computer Science Teaching Assistant in Williamstown, MA
pros: Flexible hours, very reasonable employers, a nice refresher on learned material
cons: Some of the tutorees were rather hopelessly lost or uncooperative, though they were definitely the exception rather than the norm.

review_title: A pretty good place to work
pros: Good quality of life balance and great colleagues.
cons: Don't tend to promote from within.

pros: Benefits, very supportive if you need time off for family issues
cons: Supervisors need to be more consistent in management style for all the employees on their team

job_title: Associate Director, Dining Services in Williamstown, MA
pros: Top notch college with excellent students and high standards all around.  Good facilities and excellent benefits.
cons: Williamstown is a small town in the extreme northwest corner of Massachusetts, so it's a little remote for some people.

review_title: Teaching Assistant at Top Liberal Arts College
pros: Hours are extremely flexible, and students are always respectful and receptive.
cons: hours can easily change due to other TA schedules, fills in are fairly often, and sometimes communication between TAs and professors could be better.

review_title: Great job, relaxed environment with room to grow as a computer scientist
